This change is more useful for human user than to a repeated scheduled tests. For instance, one is running a test manually and want to check another test also, then he/she can simple add another -c another_test to the command line instead of changing the existing -c original_test to -c "original_test another_test" and having to add the quotes.

Do you need to request this change for 201911 branch?
Is it required to validate the platform with the new platform test(tests/platform_tests/api/*), are the old tests (e.g.: tests/platform_tests/test_platform_info.py)going to become obsolete?

@dipali0125:

> Is it required to validate the platform with the new platform test(tests/platform_tests/api/*)

Yes. These tests are meant to ensure the platform API is fully and properly implemented on a given platform.

>are the old tests (e.g.: tests/platform_tests/test_platform_info.py)going to become obsolete?

Some tests in that file may continue to be used, but will probably be moved to become part of another suite of tests. Some have already been moved to tests/platform_tests/cli/ if they are are used to verify platform-related CLI output.

Thanks for your prompt response. Few clarifications:
Are these supported in pmon2.0 or also in older pmon?
Looking at these tests , they look more like unit tests to verify the platform apis . Is there a specific reason why the new test infrastructure was added using http requests rather than using the cli commands? 
Can we modify the exisiting tests to add verification for DUT specific info like number of fans expected, no. of psu expected?

> Are these supported in pmon2.0 or also in older pmon?
> Looking at these tests , they look more like unit tests to verify the platform apis . Is there a specific reason why the new test infrastructure was added using http requests rather than using the cli commands?

These tests are meant to verify that the vendor has fully and properly implemented the platform API 2.0 for the platform in question. Using the HTTP server to hook into the API itself is a clean way to test all API calls.

> Can we modify the exisiting tests to add verification for DUT specific info like number of fans expected, no. of psu expected?

Yes. This work is in progress. We are planning for the platform.json file to specify all the known truths for the platform (like number of PSUs, fans, etc.). Please see: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/5189

I think yes, it can be a shared function or method. Currently `creds` is a fixture. The `creds` fixture just retrieves all the pre-defined credentials in scope from ansible group and host var files. Rendering the credentials need input of variables specific to some host. It could be ptfhost, duthost or others. So, just enhancing the `creds` fixture may not be a good option. We can make it shared if we need this somewhere else in the future. By then we can have better understanding of where is the better place to add the shared function.

How about add another fixture to retrive sonic_admin_user and sonic_admin_password? I think this feature is needed by a number of cases. And I guess others may make the same mistake when use creds to get username and password.
What about the test_wr_arp.py? Is it rendered there correctly?

> What about the test_wr_arp.py? Is it rendered there correctly?

Thanks for bringing this up. Unfortunately, test_wr_arp.py needs update as well. It looks like there is a need to make it shared now. I think creds fixture is not the right place to add the Template rendering code. Such username/password are specific to different type of hosts. I'll add the code to the SonicHost class.
Please don't merge this PR for now. More updates are coming soon.

Multiple places referred to creds['sonicadmin_user'] and creds['sonicadmin_password']. It turns out rendering these two variables in the creds fixture makes more sense. I have updated this PR in that way. Thanks for all the good suggestions!
@SuvarnaMeenakshi @lguohan @yxieca

any idea why take so long? the dut ntp is trying to sync with ptf ntpd, they are on the same subnet, should be fast.

> any idea why take so long? the dut ntp is trying to sync with ptf ntpd, they are on the same subnet, should be fast.

It seems that there is a significant time gap between the DUT and ptf:
```
$ ntpq -p
     remote           refid      st t when poll reach   delay   offset  jitter
==============================================================================
 10.64.247.17    LOCAL(0)         6 u   28   64    7    0.426  -392838 282.189
```

> > any idea why take so long? the dut ntp is trying to sync with ptf ntpd, they are on the same subnet, should be fast.
> 
> It seems that there is a significant time gap between the DUT and ptf:
> 
> ```
> $ ntpq -p
>      remote           refid      st t when poll reach   delay   offset  jitter
> ==============================================================================
>  10.64.247.17    LOCAL(0)         6 u   28   64    7    0.426  -392838 282.189
> ```

if DUT does not do time jump, it will really hard for DUT to be in sync with ptf. I am not sure if increase to 480 is enough. @yxieca , should we first let DUT do a long jump?
I think this test is setup ntp to do one long jump to sync. It is still weird that the sync takes so long. But from my observation, once it is synced with the server, the clock is set.

This PR failed the vsimage check. There is issue with running the setup ansible module on localhost. If a test script declares dependency of localhost and duthost fixtures, initializing the duthost fixture would fail. The reason is that ansible tries to establish connection to the SONiC host using connection 'local' instead of 'ssh'. Probably related with calling the setup ansible module on localhost. I am still investigating. Please do not merge for now.

Fix the issue of establishing connection to SONiC host using 'local' connection. When a script depends on the localhost and duthost fixture, some global connection argument is set to 'local' while establishing connection to the localhost. Then somehow this 'local' connection is reused for duthost. The fix is simple, while establishing connection to localhost, set connection to 'smart'. Ansible will use the 'local' connection when hostname is 'localhost'. Then ansible will use 'ssh' connection to connect with SONiC host. Now this PR passed vsimage test and can be merged.
Do we need this change in 201911 and 202006?
Yes, but we don't have 201911 or 202006 branches in this repo yet.

You wrote: "RegularLAGtoVLAN test # May fail bacause FDB/ARP table is incompleted"
Should it work? Why FDB/ARP table is incomplete? Should it be updated with configured vxlan?

> You wrote: "RegularLAGtoVLAN test # May fail bacause FDB/ARP table is incompleted"
> Should it work? Why FDB/ARP table is incomplete? Should it be updated with configured vxlan?

In my opinion, the FDB and ARP table are built in **RegularLAGtoVLAN**  in **warmup**, and will be valid in a peroid (between 15 min to 45 min). As explained in ARP man page:

```
base_reachable_time (since Linux 2.2)
Once a neighbor has been found, the entry is considered to be valid for at least a random value between base_reachable_time/2 and 3*base_reachable_time/2. An entry's validity will be extended if it receives positive feedback from higher level protocols. Defaults to 30 seconds. This file is now obsolete in favor of base_reachable_time_ms.
```
And the default value of  base_reachable_time_ms is 1800000 (got from sysctl -a | grep base_reachable_time_ms). 

The Vxlan test sends only ARP reply for 192.168.0.1 from each interface, I don't think it will help DUT to refresh ARP table. To verify that, I run the test steps one by one, and nothing is changed in FDB and ARP table after Vxlan test.

```
04:02:45  =================================== FAILURES ===================================
04:02:45  ___________________ test_dhcp_relay_start_with_uplinks_down ____________________
...
```

Nevertheless, I think we need a way for the check builds to pick up test name changes.

@wangxin can we instead of removing the current dir from sys path, catch the exception with its full name?

@tahmed-dev Yes, we can specify full name to catch the exceptions. But it would be better to enforce importing from the tests package to avoid other potential similar issues that are kind of difficult to troubleshoot.

If we have rx/tx count less than the threshold to start with, clearing the portstat and then checking the count does not tell us if the portstat were really cleared.
To overcome this, we issued a ping to send large number of packets ,e.g.100, and then check that the portstat shows count greater than 100. Then clear the portstat and check that the count is less than 100. This assures that the portstat were really cleared.

> If we have rx/tx count less than the threshold to start with, clearing the portstat and then checking the count does not tell us if the portstat were really cleared.
> To overcome this, we issued a ping to send large number of packets ,e.g.100, and then check that the portstat shows count greater than 100. Then clear the portstat and check that the count is less than 100. This assures that the portstat were really cleared.

Good idea. But the ping only increases tx counters on a certain port. How could we increase tx and rx counter on each port? 
Using the ptf container may be an option, but the case will be much more complicated.

current t0 route announce does not advertise the vip prefix. I believe in order for the test to work, we need to develop a fixture that leverage the exabgp to advertise the vip prefix. I cannot find this test has that configuration.
please also move the test into bgp subfolder.

With PR https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/pull/1692, the vips routes can be announced to the t0 VMs that have the vips configuration.

Since the vips routes are part of the topology definition. IMO, it's OK to announce the vips routes in the fib fixture.
